p: In recent decades, detailed ethnobotanical studies have revealed the widespread use of wild plants in the Mediterranean basin [ 1, 2, 3, 4]. Ethnobotany is a multidisciplinary investigation of interrelations between people and plants [ 5], and plays a key role in ascertaining the various plant species used in traditional cuisine. Indeed, ethnobotany of food plants is a fairly well-developed research field in several geographical areas and social communities [ 6, 7, 8]. Moreover, ethnobotanical studies concerning food plants offer novel ways to analyze and preserve traditional knowledge and agrobiodiversity in the Mediterranean area [ 3].
